title: Yet Another Permuation Problem
statement:
The Coders Cup begins on Monday! Now, the head of Competitive Programming, Mr. Taaha, wants to make a seating arrangement for all the teams. To keep the CP vibe alive even here, he decides that the arrangement should follow a very mathematical pattern.

There are n teams numbered from 1 to n, and seats are also numbered from 1 to n. Mr. Taaha wants to arrange the teams in such a way that the absolute difference between the team’s number and their seat number is exactly k.

Formally, for every position i (1-indexed), the team sitting at that position should have a number p[i] such that |p[i] - i| = k.

Among all possible valid seatings, Taaha wants the lexicographically smallest arrangement. If no valid arrangement exists, print -1.

Your task is to help him find this special seating plan so the Coders Cup can begin in perfect CP symmetry!
input: The first line contains an integer t — the number of test cases (1 ≤ t ≤ 10). Each of the next t lines contains two space-separated integers n and k (1 ≤ n ≤ 105, 0 ≤ k ≤ n).
output: If a seating plan does not exist, print -1, otherwise print n space-separated integers representing the lexicographically smallest valid arrangement.
